Morning Everyone !
Tech Tip Tuesday ! ü™¥‚òòÔ∏èüå±üèµÔ∏è

**Headline:** "I use ChatGPT to keep my houseplants happy ‚Äî try these 5 game-changing prompts"
**Source / Date:** Tom's Guide, May 31, 2025
**Link:** https://www.tomsguide.com/ai/i-use-chatgpt-to-keep-my-houseplants-happy-try-these-5-game-changing-prompts
**Tip Summary:** This article demonstrates how ChatGPT can assist in plant care by providing tailored advice based on specific plant conditions. The author shares five effective prompts to diagnose plant issues, create customized care schedules, recommend optimal lighting setups, set up seasonal watering reminders, and identify unknown plants. By leveraging AI, plant enthusiasts can enhance their plant care routines, leading to healthier and happier houseplants.
**Action Step:** Ask ChatGPT: "My \[plant name] has \[describe symptoms]. It gets \[describe light], and I water it \[how often]. What could be the problem?"

After listening to the podcast and reading Melinda's tips I think this could be a good point of discussion for tomorrow's session!

After listening to that podcast, I did some digging on where neuroscience stands in ‚Äúdecoding the human self.‚Äù The field is edging toward reading intentions, emotions‚Äîeven fragments of inner speech‚Äîstraight from brain activity. If that trend continues, the old notion of privacy may no longer cover what most needs protecting.

So here are the two questions I keep coming back to:** Do we need to rethink and expand our definition of human rights to include explicit ‚Äúneuro-rights‚Äù that safeguard mental privacy and agency? 
And of course: Where does AI come into the picture?**

I‚Äôd love to hear everyone‚Äôs thoughts‚Äîespecially on where the line should be drawn between scientific, technological progress and personal sovereignty.

What is thought? Do we know? And if neuroscience can't answer this basic question, how can we say that AI is better or worse than human intelligence?

https://g.co/kgs/pTShigc

Look for other videos of Rafael Yuste and tell me Saturday your opinion.
I will be present. I will think about some topics!
Thanks a lot, dear friend!
Happy travels, and happy celebrations, Ekaterina.

üß¢ Buddy Group 4 | Saturday Session 

Topic: Exploring "Slow AI"
Date & Time: Saturday, 24.5., 11:00‚Äì11:40
Facilitator: Melinda

**What's on the agenda?**

We'll delve into the concept of Slow AI, a movement that reimagines AI development by prioritizing ethical, inclusive, and sustainable practices over rapid, profit-driven advancements. Inspired by the broader "slow movement" (e.g., slow food, slow fashion), it emphasizes thoughtful design, community engagement, and long-term impact.

Key Discussion Points:
- What is Slow AI, and how does it contrast with traditional AI development approaches?
- Can Slow AI principles be integrated into our current AI projects and practices?
- What are the potential benefits and challenges of adopting a Slow AI approach?

**Why should you join?**

This session offers a unique opportunity to:
- Engage in meaningful discussions about the future of AI.
- Reflect on how we, as AI professionals, can contribute to more ethical and inclusive AI development.
- Collaborate with peers to explore alternative narratives and practices in AI.

Looking forward to an enriching conversation with all of you! **Do you have any objections?**

Note: Val Sedounik will join us.

üëâ When we draft our questions, **let‚Äôs aim for short, concise wording and include a reference link to addressed information so everyone can read the source.** 

üëâ In general keep in mind: Ask a crisp question Dr. S√°nchez can answer in one breath (2 min.). However, this Friday Oscar will lead the QnA (https://www.linkedin.com/events/7331033014556123136/comments/) as mentioned in the announcement (https://discordapp.com/channels/1353058864810950737/1366389688620945408/1374715961772609666).

To conclude, I took the liberty to rephrase the question:

> The ‚ÄúAbsolute Zero‚Äù paper trains an LLM entirely on self-generated tasks, with no external data or oversight. Which guardrails‚Äîsuch as periodic human checkpoints, red-team evaluations, or hybrid data mixing‚Äîdo you see as essential to keep these self-play systems safe, aligned, and grounded in real-world values?

Reference
arXiv: 2505.03335 ‚Äî PDF: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.03335

hello everyone, i've read this article "Absolute Zero: Reinforced Self-play Reasoning with Zero Data‚Äú (arXiv:2505.03335) ", i do not remember who and where exactly posted it originally. That makes me sort or really scare, so i would like to ask how real the danger, what Dr. Sanchez would think about risks like  1. Uncontrollable reasoning paths
When a model generates its own problems, solutions, and rewards, it can quickly drift into a self-reinforcing internal logic ‚Äì without external correction or grounding.

2. Lack of real-world grounding
Without human input, the model may improve its reasoning abilities, but it lacks alignment with human values, context, and social norms.

3. Self-amplifying black-box behavior
In the absence of external data and oversight, systemic errors or biases can reinforce themselves ‚Äì and remain undetected.
let us not miss this opportunity to learn more about our incredible community!

**Since it‚Äôs first come, first served,** I‚Äôll start with Chiara‚Äôs excellent question ‚Äî which was the first one submitted and immediately set a high bar. üëè

    ‚ÄúAs generative AI systems scale and integrate across domains (from content to decision-making tools), should we rethink ‚Äòexplainability‚Äô as a system-level property rather than a model feature? What new patterns or architectural shifts could support end-to-end traceability and contextual reasoning in increasingly modular and agentic AI environments?‚Äù

Chiara‚Äôs question touches a core challenge of our time ‚Äî the shift from model-centric to system-centric thinking in AI design. Hopefully Dr. Sanchez unpacks it tomorrow in the Q&A.

dear all, here is my suggestion, regarding to this study  https://www.netzwoche.ch/news/2025-03-30/ki-tools-beeintraechtigen-kritisches-denken and other discussions, Critical Thinking and AI Literacy are extremely important. Effectively using LLMs requires a high level of critical thinking and media literacy. Current discussions focus on how education systems need to adapt in order to foster these skills and ensure responsible use of AI technologies. Key questions include:

How can we teach students not just how to use AI, but how to question and reflect on its outputs ‚Äì especially when younger generations often use it intuitively but rarely critically?

What are the risks of relying on AI tools without understanding how they work ‚Äì and how do we address this growing knowledge gap?

How can we foster a broader public conversation that treats AI not as a threat or a miracle, but as a powerful tool that must be used wisely?

Here‚Äôs my proposed question for this week: ‚ÄúAs generative AI systems scale and integrate across domains (from content to decision-making tools), should we rethink ‚Äúexplainability‚Äù as a system-level property rather than a model feature? What new patterns or architectural shifts could support end-to-end traceability and contextual reasoning in increasingly modular and agentic AI environments?‚Äù.

As I understood Oscar:
- **Conversational Leaders **post Midweek - Discussion points in a chosen channel (e.g. philosophy, etc.) 
- **Members** interact with the posts, post topic related additional information as they wish, interact regularly with the topics posted by Conversational Leaders.  
- The **general chat **is open for everybody to post information.
- The buddy groups come up with q and a questions as a group for the q and a sessions on **Friday** and the group admin (so me & Amber) feed it back on **Thursday **> https://discordapp.com/channels/1353058864810950737/1353449293717180467.

Hi Melinda,

Thanks for the update and for checking with Oscar!

Just to confirm two things:
